newsitem.title: USA: Copper Journal sees 85 cent/lb average in 1997.
newsitem.headline: Copper Journal sees 85 cent/lb average in 1997.

text.p: The Copper Journal said despite strong near-term fundamentals, the price of copper will average about 85 cents per pound this year.
John Gross of the Copper Journal said should the spot market get to 111.00 cents and fail to advance further, it will be viewed as a sign of weakness and represent a potential selling opportunity.
On Monday spot COMEX hit 110.80 cents, its highest since just before prices crashed mid-June 1996 after Sumitomo announced huge losses from copper deals.
Midday Tuesday, COMEX March copper was traded at 106.20 cents, with spot January at 108.50 cents.
Gross said 111.00 cents was the support line until the price plunged last June, and many traders believe old support becomes new resistance.
If copper breaks through 111.00 cents, the next line of resistance would be at 120 cents.
But the volatile nature of copper should keep traders on their guard as it probes near 111.00 cents, Gross said.

"Because when the market is flashing the yellow caution signal, as it does at a support or resistance line, you want to slow down, observe how the market is responding to the signal, in order to determine if it is safe to proceed," Gross said.
